title: Basic Accounting Concepts
headline: Learn the foundational concepts of accounting, the ‘language of business’, in this free online course.
description: Accounting is crucial to the successful operation of a company since it records and analyses business activity. Understanding its basic concepts is advisable to successfully distribute the accounting role in a business of any size. This course will cover important concepts from scratch, like accounting standards, double-entry, financial statements and more, and will help you to understand these various divisions so you feel competent.
courseDescription:
Accounting is a vital activity in any business and is carried out, to some extent, in companies of every size. It is often referred to as the ‘language of business’, as it helps to track, analyse and communicate business activity. However, you must understand some vital concepts like double-entry bookkeeping and financial statements to record and interpret financial information. This short course will explain these critical concepts, starting with discussing the role and importance of accounting.

Next, you will learn about accounting standards and essential notions like the ‘going concern’ principle and ‘accrual concept’. You will also learn about double-entry bookkeeping and the process involved in accounting for inventory, drawings and expenses. Following this, you will research the equations used and the components of a balance sheet. We explain the income statement in detail and you will learn about its features like the net income, interest and expenses.

We will introduce you to trial balance and comprehensive income, financial position and cash flow statements. Finally, you will learn about budgeting and auditing in business. Whether you are a small business owner, a new bookkeeper or a prospective or seasoned accountant, the information contained within this course will help you understand the role and concepts of accounting or serve as a reference document for important business information. Start now and learn the basic accounting concepts in under three hours.

Start Course Now

  • Lesson Summary

    • Accounting provides the data necessary to effectively operate a company, optimise income and minimise costs. Accounting is the language of business.
    • Accounting encompasses more than just bookkeeping. An accountant is an individual responsible for creating, maintaining and interpreting financial records.
    • There are three main types of accountants – public, management and government accountants.
    • Accounting concepts like the accrual and prudence concept, are used in constructing financial statements.
    • Accounting concepts are a guide to the proper way of creating statements and records. Accounting standards usually apply to limited companies and are based on accounting concepts.
    • Accounting standards are not law, and business could decide to ignore the guidance of a given standard.
    • The account where a transaction is recorded, depends on the nature of transaction. Drawings refer to business resources taken out for personal use.
    • Inventory refers to products that a company purchases with the intention of selling for a profit. Each transaction has two distinct effects, and these effects must reflect in separate accounts.
    • A balance sheet provides a picture of the financial health of a business. Assets are resources with economic value, while liabilities are financial obligations of a business.
    • Owners equity refers to the amount invested in a business, by its owner.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • On the successful completion of this course, you will be able to;
    • Summarise the importance of financial statements.
    • Explain the accounting equation.
    • Differentiate between the cash flow statement and balance sheet.
    • Identify the formula for calculating net profit.
    • Distinguish between control and planning.
    • Explain the importance of external auditing.

  • Lesson Summary

    • The Income Statement summarises a company's revenues and expenses for a specified period.
    • Net income is the difference between the revenue generated by a company, and the expenses incurred during the same period. Net income is also referred to as the 'bottom line'.
    • Revenue and expenses are recorded based on the accrual concept. Financial statements depict the financial position and performance of a business over a period of time.
    • Trial balance lists the closing balances on each ledger account. The total value of assets should equal the sum of capital and liabilities.
    • The cash flow statement shows the transactions that have changed cash levels during a time period. 
    • The cash flow statement is divided into three major areas, operating activities, financial activities, and investment activities.
    • Gross profit is the difference between direct sales and direct expenditures. Budgets are a detailed plan of future expectations in quantitative terms.
    • Budget forecasts are essential components of a business plan. A key element of budgeting is the preparation of a capital expenditures budget.
    • Financial audits are an objective examination of an organization's financial statements. There are three main types of audits – internal, external, and internal revenue audits.
